node.text:
"I would describe cryptocurrencies as a limited supply of nothing."

John Paulson—who's famous bet against subprime housing made him and investors $20 billion—says crypto is a "worthless" bubble and he calls SPACs, one of the hottest investing tools, a losing proposition.

Paulson told @bloombergtv in an interview on "Bloomberg Wealth with David Rubenstein" he's more concerned about rising prices. The rapidly expanding money supply could push inflation rates well above current expectations, he said, and gold, which he’s backed for years, is primed for its moment.

Paulson’s dismissal of crypto is sure to attract critics after digital assets vastly outperformed gold in recent years. Watch the full episode Tuesday at 9pm ET on BloombergTV and read the Big Take in our stories.

node.title: Cryptocurrencies are a Bubble, Says Billionaire Paulson

node.text: Frackers in America’s largest oil field are letting massive amounts of methane spill into the atmosphere. These scientists and activists are trying to find the leaks and get them plugged before they cook the planet further.

node.title: The Methane Hunters Racing to Change the Course of Global Warming

node.text:
Astra + Pfizer = ?
Moderna + Sinovac = ?

In some countries, people have received a mixture of Covid vaccines. Nicole Sy breaks down what that could mean for the world's vaccinated, and those still waiting on their first shot. (via @quicktake)

node.title: What Happens When You Mix Covid Vaccines?

node.text: Few people have lost as much money as quickly as Bill Hwang. In March, the previously unknown Wall Street whale and his family firm, Archegos, triggered losses of more than $20 billion in just two days. The result was one of the most spectacular implosions in modern financial history. (via @businessweek)

node.title: How Archegos Capital Cost Wall Street $20 Billion

node.text: Almost 30 years ago, an American court ruled that victims of the Ferdinand Marcos regime in the Philippines should be compensated — setting off one of the most ambitious and valuable treasure hunts of all time. (via @businessweek)

node.title: Where Did Marcos Hide His $10 Billion Fortune?

node.text: Airbnb's $100 billion business model is built on strangers trusting each other. When things go horribly wrong, the company's secretive safety team steps in to soothe guests and hosts, help families and prevent PR disasters. (via @businessweek)

node.text:
China's growing ranks of rural entrepreneurs are getting rich peddling their produce on social media. 

One of the scene's stars is Jin Guowei, aka Brother Pomegranate — an internet sensation with 7.3 million followers and 300 million yuan ($46 million) of sales in 2020. (video via @quicktake)

node.title: Livestreaming Farmers Earn Millions From Fruit on China’s TikTok

node.text:
In almost every way measurable, millennials in the U.S. at 40 are doing worse financially than the generations that came before them.

Fewer millennials own homes than their parents did at their age. They have more debt — especially student debt. They simply aren’t as wealthy. 

Now, if predictions of a long, post-Covid economic boom are to be believed, this may be the last opportunity an entire generation has to build wealth before heading off into retirement.

node.title: Millennials Are Running Out of Time to Build Wealth to Retire

node.text: When employees at software company 10Pines want a raise, they pitch their co-workers, not their boss. Here's what happens when a firm uses "radical transparency" to attract and retain talent.

node.title: Would You Let Your Colleagues Decide Your Salary?

node.text:
While the "15-minute city" model promotes neighborhood-level urban planning, Sweden is pursuing a hyper-local twist: a scheme to redesign every street in the nation.

For more, read the report by @citylab: bloomberg.com/citylab/design

node.text:
Two of the world's wealthiest individuals will attempt to fly into space just nine days apart.

Here's how their space trips compare. (via @quicktake)

node.title: Billionaire Space Race: Branson vs. Bezos

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 02, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and text that says '1 P ท Jessica Simpson is set to buy her name from bankruptcy for $65 million Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Jessica Simpson's family offered to buy the singer-turned-entrepreneur's fashion brand after the parent company that owns the rights to her collection went bankrupt.
 
Sequential Brands Group, which also owns Joe’s Jeans, filed its Chapter 11 petition earlier this week after struggling with changing consumer habits and the fallout from the pandemic.

It now plans to sell its brands at auction but has reached a tentative deal with the Simpson family, according to a company attorney. Link in bio for more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 02, 2021. May be an image of text that says '9 10 1112 13-18 Durchwahl says there's no urgent need for shots RENX Bloomberg'.

node.text:
European Union health authorities said there is not currently a case for widespread use of Covid-19 vaccine booster shots, though people with weakened immune systems should be offered a third dose.

The priority now should be to vaccinate the roughly one-third of Europe’s adults who aren’t fully inoculated, the European Medicines Agency said. The statement is in line with guidance issued earlier this week in the U.K., but differs from policy in the U.S. The Biden administration has sought to give a top-up to healthy, fully-vaccinated people, potentially to ward off the more contagious delta variant — even as some public health experts warn that reaching the unvaccinated should remain a higher priority.

Tap the link in our bio for more.

The remnants of Hurricane Ida ripped through New York and New Jersey, killing at least eight people and triggering torrential rain that paralyzed transport services. 

Video on social media showed major thoroughways, airport terminals, baseball stadiums and subway stations turned into wading pools. Tornadoes were reported across Maryland and New Jersey.

Mayor Bill de Blasio declared an emergency for New York City and Governor Kathy Hochul did the same for the state. Tap the link in our bio for the latest. (via @quicktake)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business in Bronx, New York. May be an image of motorcycle, street, road and text that says 'New York City sees flash flooding as remnants of Hurricaneldahit Bloomberg'.

node.text:
New York City declared a state of emergency as heavy rain pummeled the region, submerging subway tracks and train stations and leaving thousands without power.

The National Weather Service issued a rare Flash Flood Emergency for New York City and Northeast New Jersey, predicting 3 to 5 inches of rainfall an hour. Mayor Bill de Blasio said the city was “enduring an historic weather event” and residents should “get to safety now.”

Downpours halted train services, downed trees and flooded streets across the region. Some areas — including Newark Airport — got the equivalent of seven weeks of average rainfall in a few hours. Tap the link in our bio for the latest.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 01, 2021. May be an image of sky and text that says 'House prices in three U.S. cities have jumped 25% or more 25%y injusta Bloomberg Wealth'.

node.text:
Homes in some of the largest U.S. cities just keep getting more expensive.

In Phoenix alone, an index that measures home prices climbed a whopping 29.3% in June from the previous year, as more people move to the city. The measure in San Diego rose 27.1%, while Seattle increased 25%. The index in nine cities jumped 20% or more.

Overall, in the 20 cities measured by the S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller data, the index rose 18.6% in June from a year earlier. That’s the largest surge since 1988. Tap the link in our bio for more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 01, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says '00000 Florida's Wall Street South is building its own New York Bloomberg'.

node.text:
The pandemic supercharged the migration of New York’s elite to tax-friendly Florida, fueling a surge in luxury real estate, golf-club memberships and private-school enrollments. Now local developers and entrepreneurs are looking to transform once-sleepy West Palm Beach into a thriving center of finance.

That means new power-dining hotspots, after-work bars, gleaming towers and even an entirely new neighborhood that nods to Manhattan’s West Village.

But how many young finance professionals are really ready to leave New York City behind? Read more at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 01, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says '00000 Florida's Wall Street South is building its own New York Bloomberg'.

Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says '00000O The old Wall Street has Harry's, the venerable watering-hole frequented by the power-brokers of American finance. The Harry's in West Palm Beach will sit in 360 Rosemary, whose terracotta design some New Yorkers say reminds them of 10 Bond Street. The building will also house Goldmar Sachs and Steve Cohen's Point72. Bloomberg'.
Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 01, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'Bloomberg'.

Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 01, 2021. May be an image of sky and text that says 'The Bristol, West Palm's first ultra-luxury waterfront condo, sold out after Covid hit. In nearby neighborhoods, homes were snapped up at record prices. Bloomberg'.

Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 01, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'zaếe 0Q0 The owners of Manhattan's 310 Bowery are partners in 123 Datura, a bar that touts its "NYC roots" It's become the clubhouse for 20-something transplants. NoRA, a block of commercial properties on North Railroad Avenue, will repurpose 1920s industrial buildings and bring in cobblestone streets "like in the West Village." Bloomberg'.
Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 01, 2021. May be an image of skyscraper, sky and text that says 'H Bloomberg'.
Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 01, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'FACE Silent, painless organ damage seen in Covid "long haulers" Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Kidney damage is painless and silent and, according to a new study, it could affect a swath of Covid-19 survivors.
 
Research published in the Journal of the American Society of Nephrology suggests even those who recover from the coronavirus without being hospitalized can experience injury to the organ. Survivors also face an increased risk of developing acute kidney disease, according to the findings.

Ziyad Al-Aly, the epidemiologist who led the study, said a “huge number” of people could be affected. Tap the link in our bio to read in full.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business in Edinburgh, United Kingdom. May be an image of 1 person, standing, outdoors and text that says '11111 Scotland urged to expandits trial of afour afour-dayweek week Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Fancy a four-day week? Scotland might be the place.
 
The pro-independence Scottish National Party promised in its election manifesto to test the idea of a shorter working week. The focus is on improving the well-being of employees without their losing pay. 

A prominent think tank now suggests that a trial involving office workers should be expanded across other areas of the economy as part of the nation's post-Covid recovery. Tap the link in our bio to find out more.

📷: Jeff J Mitchell/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Chinese hedge funds are paying $300,000 to beat Wall Street to thebestgraduates Bloomb erg Wealth'.

node.text:
$100,000 for freshly minted graduates on Wall Street? Pocket change.
 
China's booming hedge fund industry is offering top college grads starting salaries of as much of $300,000 — about triple the going rate at top U.S. banks, even after recent pay boosts.
 
The super-sized salaries are being deployed to encourage elite candidates to start their careers at home rather than going abroad, and to help finance firms compete with tech giants for the best talent. Tap the link in our bio for more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 31, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, sitting and text that says 'Dưசnh -Goldman trader builds unicorn after being denieda credit card Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Russell Cummer was a credit trader at Goldman Sachs in Tokyo when he tried and failed to get a credit card.

It’s a common tale in Japan, especially for young people with no credit history. Cummer’s response was decidedly uncommon: He ended up forming a business to give people an alternative to cards.
Paidy, whose backers include Soros Capital Management and Visa, is now one of a handful of unlisted startups in Japan with a valuation of at least $1 billion and among the largest players in its “buy now, pay later” sector. Find out more at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 31, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'One in four bosses say they 've fired someone over a Zoom-callblunder Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Nearly one in four executives have fired a staffer for slipping up during a video or audio conference, and most have levied some sort of disciplinary action for gaffes made in virtual meetings, a survey of 200 managers at large companies found.

The survey, commissioned by Vyopta, also found that bosses don’t fully trust a third of their staff to perform effectively when working remotely. Tap the link in bio for more.

📷: Leo Patrizi/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 31, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, people playing sports and text that says 'addds GREAT BRITA AN KERR NORW. INGEBRIGTSEN KENYA KIPSAN KONN Nike's "super shoes" sparkarace arace to outfit the world'srunners world's Bloomberg'.

node.text:
It all started with the somewhat controversial “super shoe” technology — pioneered by Nike with springy foam and hard plates in thick soles — that made the world’s top marathoners faster by providing a trampoline effect with every stride.

Companies then started putting those components in track spikes, historically a niche market of minimalist footwear that now includes bestsellers like the fat-soled, carbon fiber-plated $180 Nike Air Zoom Victory.

Now those same features are filtering down to sneakers designed for the masses as running shoe makers race to increase their share of a global market worth more than $10 billion. Tap the link in bio for more.

📷: Britain’s Josh Kerr, left, wore shoes designed by Nike when he won bronze in the men’s 1,500-meter final in Tokyo. By Martin Rickett/PA Images/Getty Images
